problems.title: Redstone?
problems.statementHtml:
Steve stumbled upon a collection of nn gears, where gear ii has aiai teeth, and he wants to arrange them into a row.

After he arranges them, Steve will spin the leftmost gear at a speed of 11 revolution per second. For each of the other gears, let xx be the number of teeth it has, yy be the number of teeth of the gear to its left, and zz be the speed the gear to its left spins at. Then, its speed will be yx⋅zyx⋅z revolutions per second.

Steve considers the contraption satisfactory if the rightmost gear spins at a speed of 11 revolution per second. Determine whether Steve can rearrange the gears into a satisfactory contraption.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤1002≤n≤100) — the number of gears Steve has.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (2≤ai≤1002≤ai≤100) — the number of teeth of each gear.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print "YES" if Steve can rearrange the gears in a satisfactory way, and "NO" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the second gear will always spin at speed 55⋅1=155⋅1=1 revolution per second, so any arrangement is satisfactory.

In the second test case, one possible arrangement is [6,3,9,6][6,3,9,6]. Then:

  • The second gear spins at speed 63⋅1=263⋅1=2 revolutions per second.
  • The third gear spins at speed 39⋅2=2339⋅2=23 revolutions per second.
  • The fourth spins at speed 96⋅23=196⋅23=1 revolution per second.
Since the rightmost gear spins at a speed of 11 revolution per second, the arrangement is satisfactory.

In the third test case, neither of the possible arrangements [2,3][2,3] and [3,2][3,2] are satisfactory.

problems.title: Villagers
problems.statementHtml:
Steve lives in a village with nn other villagers. Unfortunately, due to disputes over the distribution of emeralds, none of those villagers are friends with any other villager. Furthermore, villager ii initially has a grumpiness of gigi.

Steve can perform the following operation any number of times:

Steve wishes to make every villager friends with every other villager (possibly through some intermediate friendships); that is, from any villager, you can follow a path of friendships to reach any other villager. Since he does not want to inflate the village economy too much, calculate the minimum number of emeralds he must give away to accomplish this.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of villagers.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers g1,g2,…,gng1,g2,…,gn (1≤gi≤1091≤gi≤109) — the initial grumpiness of each villager.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum number of emeralds Steve must give away to make everyone friends.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the only valid operation is i=1i=1, j=2j=2. Steve gives them max(1,2)=2max(1,2)=2 emeralds, and they become friends.

In the second test case, one optimal sequence of operations is as follows:

  • Steve chooses i=1i=1, j=3j=3. He gives the villagers max(2,5)=5max(2,5)=5 emeralds, and their grumpiness decreases by min(2,5)=2min(2,5)=2. Now everyone's grumpiness is [0,1,3,2][0,1,3,2];
  • Steve chooses i=2i=2, j=4j=4. He gives the villagers max(1,2)=2max(1,2)=2 emeralds, and their grumpiness decreases by min(1,2)=1min(1,2)=1. Now everyone's grumpiness is [0,0,3,1][0,0,3,1];
  • Steve chooses i=1i=1, j=2j=2. He gives the villagers max(0,0)=0max(0,0)=0 emeralds, and their grumpiness decreases by min(0,0)=0min(0,0)=0. Now everyone's grumpiness is [0,0,3,1][0,0,3,1].

After this, the pairs of villagers (1,3)(1,3), (2,4)(2,4) and (1,2)(1,2) are directly friends, and every other pair of villagers is connected by a chain of mutual friendships. It can be shown that Steve cannot spend fewer than 77 emeralds to accomplish this.

problems.title: The Nether
problems.statementHtml:
This is an interactive problem.

Having recently discovered The Nether, Steve has built a network of nn nether portals, each at a different location in his world.

Each portal is connected in one direction to some number (possibly zero) of other portals. To avoid getting lost, Steve has carefully built the network of portals so that there is no sequence of jumps through portals that will bring you from a location back to itself; formally, the network forms a directed acyclic graph.

Steve refuses to tell you which portals are connected to which, but he will allow you to ask queries. In each query, you give Steve a set of locations S={s1,s2,…,sk}S={s1,s2,…,sk} and a starting location x∈Sx∈S. Steve will figure out the longest path starting at xx that only passes through locations in SS and tell you the number of locations in it. (If it is impossible to reach any other location in SS from xx, Steve will reply with 11.)

As you are looking to obtain the achievement "Hot Tourist Destinations", you want to find any path that visits as many locations as possible. Steve is feeling particularly generous and will give you 2⋅n2⋅n queries to find it.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤5002≤n≤500) — the number of locations.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n3n3 over all test cases does not exceed 50035003.

Interaction

The interaction for each test case begins with reading the integer nn. Then you can make up to 2⋅n2⋅n queries.

To make a query, output a line in the following format:

  • ?xks1s2…sk?xks1s2…sk

The jury will return the answer to the query.

When you find a path with maximum length, output a single line in the following format:

  • !kv1v2…vk!kv1v2…vk

This denotes starting at portal v1v1, then jumping to v2v2, then to v3v3 and so on, ending at vkvk.

Note that outputting the answer does not count towards the limit of 2⋅n2⋅n queries.

After printing each query do not forget to output the end of line and flush∗∗ the output. Otherwise, you will get Idleness limit exceeded verdict.

If, at any interaction step, you read −1−1 instead of valid data, your solution must exit immediately. This means that your solution will receive Wrong answer because of an invalid query or any other mistake. Failing to exit can result in an arbitrary verdict because your solution will continue to read from a closed stream.

The interactor is not adaptive. The connections between portals do not change during the interaction.

Hacks

To perform a hack, use the following format:

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤5002≤n≤500) — the number of locations.

Then, output nn lines. The ii-th line should be of the form kiv1v2…vkikiv1v2…vki (0≤ki≤n−10≤ki≤n−1, 1≤vj≤n1≤vj≤n, vj≠ivj≠i), denoting that the portal at location ii is connected in one direction (leads to) locations v1,v2,…,vkiv1,v2,…,vki. The given network must form a directed acyclic graph.

The sum of n3n3 over all test cases must not exceed 50035003.

∗∗To flush, use:

  • fflush(stdout) or cout.flush() in C++;
  • sys.stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the network of portals is as follows:

  • The longest path starting at location 11 passing only through {1,2,3,4}{1,2,3,4} is the path 1→4→21→4→2, which has 33 distinct locations.
  • The longest path starting at location 33 passing only through {2,3,4}{2,3,4} is the path 3→4→23→4→2, which has 33 distinct locations.
  • The longest path starting at location 55 passing only through {1,5}{1,5} is the path 5→15→1, which has 22 distinct locations.
  • It is impossible to get to any other location in {2,4}{2,4} starting from 22, so Steve answers 11 for that query.
Using the information from these queries, it is possible to determine that a longest path is 5→1→4→25→1→4→2.

In the second test case, the network of portals is as follows:

Neither of the portals is connected to the other, so the longest path is a single location. Note that ! 1 2 would also be a valid answer.

problems.title: Chicken Jockey
problems.statementHtml:
Steve made the foolish decision to mine at night, and came across a monstrous creature: the chicken jockeynn!

A chicken jockeynn consists of nn mobs stacked in order on top of each other, with mob 11 at the bottom and mob nn at the top. Mob ii initially has hihi health.

In one attack, Steve can deal 11 damage to any mob. If any mob reaches 00 or less health, it dies, and all the mobs on top of it fall down and form a new stack. The bottom mob in the new stack takes 11 fall damage for every mob it was on top of before falling (i.e. the number of mobs below it in the previous stack, including the one that just died). This may kill it as well, in which case all mobs on top of it fall down again and the process repeats.

For example, consider a chicken jockey66 with initial mob healths [1,2,1,3,5,2][1,2,1,3,5,2]. If Steve damages the third mob in the stack, it dies and the mobs with health [3,5,2][3,5,2] fall down in a new stack. The bottom mob takes 33 units of fall damage so it also dies, and the mobs with health [5,2][5,2] fall down in a new stack. The bottom mob takes 11 unit of fall damage. As a result, after Steve's first attack, there will be two stacks with healths [1,2][1,2] and [4,2][4,2].

Steve's sword's durability is low, so he wishes to know the minimum attacks required to kill all the mobs.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of mobs.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers h1,h2,…,hnh1,h2,…,hn (1≤hi≤1091≤hi≤109) — the initial health of each mob.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum attacks required to kill all the mobs.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the initial stack has mobs with health [3,1,4,1,2][3,1,4,1,2]. Steve can use one attack to damage the second mob in the stack and kill it. The third mob takes 22 units of fall damage. There are now two stacks: [3][3] and [2,1,2][2,1,2]. Now Steve can kill the second mob in the second stack. The third mob in the stack takes 22 units of fall damage, killing it. There are now two stacks: [3][3] and [2][2]. Finally, Steve can use five attacks to kill the remaining mobs.

In the second test case, Steve can deal 11 damage to the bottom mob in the stack. When it dies, the second mob will take 11 unit of fall damage and die; then the third mob will take 11 unit of fall damage and die; finally the fourth mob will take 11 unit of fall damage and die.

problems.title: I Yearned For The Mines
problems.statementHtml:
As a child, Steve yearned for the mines! His mine can be represented as a tree∗∗ of nn nodes.

Unfortunately, Steve's mine has been infiltrated by his greatest nemesis, Herobrine! At any time, Herobrine is hiding in exactly one node; initially, he may be in any of them. Steve can perform the following operations:

Find a sequence of at most ⌊54⋅n⌋⌊54⋅n⌋ operations that will guarantee Steve catches Herobrine, regardless of Herobrine's initial location and moves. We have a proof that, under the given constraints, this is always possible.

∗∗A tree is a connected graph without cycles.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of nodes.

Each of the next n−1n−1 lines contains two integers uu and vv (1≤u,v≤n1≤u,v≤n), describing an edge between nodes uu and vv.

It is guaranteed that the given edges form a tree.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, first output a single integer kk (1≤k≤⌊54⋅n⌋1≤k≤⌊54⋅n⌋) — the number of operations you wish to perform.

Then output kk lines. Line ii (1≤i≤k1≤i≤k) should contain two integers titi and xixi (1≤ti≤21≤ti≤2, 1≤xi≤n1≤xi≤n), indicating that the ii-th operation you wish to perform is operation titi on node xixi.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the tree is as follows:

Initially, Herobrine may be in either of the nodes. After the first operation, which checks node 11, if Herobrine was in node 11, he would be caught, so the only possible node he could be in after the operation is node 22 (he cannot move to node 11 since it was just checked). Therefore, after the second operation, which checks node 22, he must have been caught.

In the second test case, the tree is as follows:

Initially, Herobrine may be in any of the nodes [1,2,3,4][1,2,3,4]. After the first operation, Herobrine can only be in nodes [1,3,4][1,3,4]. The second operation destroys all edges adjacent to node 22. Since all the edges connected to nodes 11, 33, and 44 are now destroyed, Herobrine is unable to move any more no matter where he is located. So after checking those three nodes in operations 33, 44, and 55, he is guaranteed to have been caught.

problems.title: Flint and Steel
problems.statementHtml:
Steve's creeper farm has overflowed and there are creepers everywhere! There are nn creepers standing in a line, with the ii-th creeper having explosive power eiei. Steve needs to kill all of them in order to get past.

To do this, he can use his trusty Flint and Steel to detonate creepers. Detonating the creeper at position ii kills all creepers at positions jj such that |i−j|<ei|i−j|<ei. Dead creepers cannot be detonated. Some creepers may be particularly weak and have explosive power 00, meaning they cannot be detonated either.

With the Great Hog hot on his tail, there is no time to waste. Find a sequence of detonations that kills all the creepers with as few detonations as possible, or report it is impossible.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤5⋅1052≤n≤5⋅105) — the number of creepers.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers e1,e2,…,ene1,e2,…,en (0≤ei≤n0≤ei≤n) — the explosive power of each creeper.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1055⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output −1−1 if it is impossible to kill all the creepers.

Otherwise, output two lines. On the first line, output a single integer kk (1≤k≤n1≤k≤n), the minimum number of detonations needed. Then output a line with kk integers d1,d2,…,dkd1,d2,…,dk (1≤di≤n1≤di≤n), stating the sequence of creepers to detonate.

If there are multiple solutions, you can print any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the sequence of detonations is as follows:

  • 0,2,2––––––,3,0,10,2,2_,3,0,1
  • ×,×,×,3,0,1–––––––––––×,×,×,3,0,1_
  • ×,×,×,×,×,××,×,×,×,×,×
where ×× represents a dead creeper. Note that if Steve had first detonated creeper 44 instead, the only creeper left alive would be creeper 11 which cannot be detonated.

In the second test case, creeper 11 cannot be detonated, and none of creepers 22, 33 or 44 have a high enough explosive power to kill it, so there is no solution.

In the fifth test case, the sequence of detonations is as follows:

  • 2,0––––,2,4,2,2,4,1,12,0_,2,4,2,2,4,1,1
  • ×,×,2,4,2,2,4,1,1––––––––––––×,×,2,4,2,2,4,1,1_
  • ×,×,2,×–––––––,×,×,×,×,××,×,2,×_,×,×,×,×,×
  • ×,×,×,×,×,×,×,×,××,×,×,×,×,×,×,×,×

tutorial.contentHtml:
Thank you for participating in my round! I hope you all enjoyed it.

Rate the contest!
Quality
  • 275 Excellent contest
  • 79 Good contest
